last_replies.com:
Time limits are a pretty good way to create tension, because HBR is very heavy on burst damage that needs a while to prepare. In the same way healing bosses encourage you to gear towards burst damage to make the healing irrelevant. There are actually not that many bosses that go for drawn out confrontations.

I've said it back when I beat chapter 4.1, but the final boss having that time limit (one that you cant predict the first time) gave me an exhilarating tension that I wouldnt have gotten in a standard fight. In general that final Day messes with you. Having a sub-boss that is as strong as a real boss, having the second phase of the final boss actually get the first turn, when most player do risky plays knowing they have the first turn guaranteed... And adding a time limit that is unpredictable, unlike the one in chapter 2's final boss fight. I think it was pretty good, it certainly made it more memorable. Chapter 3's final boss mostly sticks in my head for being gross and for it's unique third phase and that is not because the fight itself was that interesting.

last_replies.com:
Looking back I realized just now that basically all the main plot events have something in common: they are about memories.

First we have the story of Bungo, who keeps losing her memories, then her opposite, Aoi who is cursed to never forget anything.
We then have Tsukasa, who is literally a different person depending on whether she has the memories of her mother's death.
The big revelation is also about how all the girls are a recreation of someone who died, and all their memories are copies. And those memories themselves (and the personality deriving from them) are what makes them what they are now.
At the same time the depressed Ruka starts accepting the situation when she realizes that she has real memories of her own, the ones she made with Yukki and the others after they enrolled.
We also saw that when the human Navis die they progressively lose their human memories, leaving their most important one for last (for Aoi the willingness of protecting others, for Kura the moment when she fell for Tsukishiro) and when they are all gone they return to be an (apparently?) empty shell as a Navi.

And then we have the Garden of Memories, the place where Ruka can relive hers.
At this point I can think of two possible meanings of this place.
One is that it's the mind of a dying Luka, who is losing her memories but she is also somehow able to reverse this process and can use the memory fragments she obtains while reviving her memories to recreate the most important memories, which are the ones of the other girls.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3837491
(cont)
The other theory is the exact opposite: near the end of the game Ruka is the only survivor but she's able to use the fragments to literally recreate/resurrect her companions. This would act as this game's (hopefully) inevitable "Key Magic" used to reach the happy ending, and it kinda reminds me of Clannad, where iirc there was the little girl who collected the light orbs you obtained by finishing the routes and then used them to "unlock" the good ending.
Ruka is the only one able to do it because she's the only one who has a bond to every character on the base, which could be the real reason why she is "special", not merely because she is stronger than the others.
The memory fragments are also the only consumable items (other than the quartz, but that's self explanatory) which counter appear in the main menu. Why putting them there if not because they are extremamely important?
It could also be that finishing the game normally gives you a bad ending (like in a normal visual novel), but if you have restored all the other girls you get the good ending.

Worth noting is that by using the fragments to restore the other characters appearance and voice in the Garden you literally obtain a specific item called "soul", which, appropriately, is unique to each character. Since the existance of souls in the human navis should be an important plot point I don't think it's a coincidence.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>3837491
Regarding Aoi's navi, it is unique from all other cases as far we can tell. While it did forget her identity and who everyone was, it kept a base of Aoi's personality and recognized the vine bracelet as its possession. Also it could tell that it likes cetain voices, it "teared up" when the girls thanked it for Aoi's hard work and it nodded when told to go play with the other navi.
Mind you, all of this happened over 2 days after Aoi's death, which directly contradicts the report Nanase read in Kura's event about navi losing all memories and reactions roughly 18 hours after death. You may think two days is maybe still an acceptable margin of error, but then there is Requiem for the Blue, where the Aoi navi still showed empathetic responses to Ichigo much later still. It tried to comfort her, which according to the data presented should not be possible. And in chapter 4 during a special Ichigo event at the navi square it is implied that she still reports back to the Aoi navi even now.

So we can conclude that Aoi's navi is special, perhaps due to a weird confluence of the copy ability taking the hyperthymesia and changing the navi permanently.

>>3837495
I think restoring the memory fragments of all the girls in the prism world is definitely going to factor in down the line. But as for the "soul items", those are tied to SS styles (meaning some character already have several) and some can be bought from the cat shop or from event exchanges, so their meaning might not be that important.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Holy shit, the artbook of citrus is fucking huge.
I didn't check the size, I thought it was the usual artbook size, now I understand why the shipment was so expensive.
The huge wedding spreads are so damn good and it's nice to have all the store exclusives I missed with the volumes, but the lack of HaruYuzu is disappointing.

Thank god cdjapan didn't go "eco", everything was wrapped in bubble wrap and every empty space in the box was filled with paper. It's probably the first time in at least one year that I haven't received any damaged book. I may stick with it despite the expensive shipping. It also said 1-3 weeks for some volumes but it shipped everything in 2 days (but Vampeerz is still out of stock). Then FedEx put it out for delivery and at the end of the day brought it back to their warehouse without delivering it. It worried me as hell but then they delivered it the next day. Their custom taxes are higher too, 11,90 € for an order of 182,05 € (6,5% against Amazon's 4%).
